ul.li1: 1My child, guard my sayings;
ul.li2: store my commandments with you.
ul.li1: 2Keep my commands and live,
ul.li2: and my teaching like the apple of your eye.A single word meaning “pupil of the eye”
ul.li1: 3Bind them on your fingers;
ul.li2: write them on the tablet of your heart.
ul.li1: 4Say to wisdom,Hebrew “the wisdom” “you are my sister,”
ul.li2: and you shall call insight,Hebrew “the insight” “intimate friend.”Literally “one who is known.” To “know” is often a euphemism for intercourse. Therefore “intimate friend” may also be read “lover.”
ul.li1: 5In order to guard yourself from an adulteress,Literally “a strange woman”
ul.li2: from the foreigner who makes her words smooth.Literally “causes to be smooth her words”
ul.li1: 6For at the window of my house,
ul.li2: through my lattice, I looked down.
ul.li1: 7And I saw among the simple,
ul.li2: I observed among the youth,
a young man lacking sense,Literally “heart”
ul.li1: 8passing on the street atLiterally “at the place of” her corner,
ul.li2: and he takes the road to her house,
ul.li1: 9at twilight, at the day’s evening,
ul.li2: in the midst of night and the darkness.
ul.li1: 10Then behold! A woman comes to meet him
ul.li2: with the garment of a prostituteOr “whore” and a secret heart.Literally “secret of heart”
ul.li1: 11She is loud and stubborn;
ul.li2: her feet do not stay at her house.
ul.li1: 12Now in the street, now in the square,
ul.li2: atLiterally “at the place of” every corner she lies in wait.
ul.li1: 13She took hold of Or “strengthened” him and kissed him.
ul.li2: Her face was impudent, and she said to him,
ul.li1: 14“Sacrifices of peace offerings are upon me;
ul.li2: todayLiterally “the day” I completed my vows.
ul.li1: 15SoHebrew “thus” I have come out to meet you,
ul.li2: to seek your face, and I have found you.
ul.li1: 16With coverings I have adorned my couch,
ul.li2: spreads of the linen of Egypt;
ul.li1: 17I have perfumed my bed with myrrh,
ul.li2: aloes, and cinnamon.
ul.li1: 18Come, let us take our fill of love making,
ul.li2: until the morning let us delight in love.
ul.li1: 19For there is no manOr “husband” in his home;
ul.li2: he has gone on a long journey.Literally “a journey from far”
ul.li1: 20The bag of money he took in his hand,
ul.li2: for on the day of the full moon he will come home.”
ul.li1: 21She persuades him with the greatness of her teachings;
ul.li2: with her smooth lips she compels him.
ul.li1: 22He goes after her suddenly;
ul.li2: like an ox to the slaughter he goes,
and like a stag to the instruction of a fool,
ul.li1: 23until an arrow pierces his entrails,Literally “heaviness,” often referring to the liver
ul.li2: like a bird rushing into a snare,
but he does not know that it will cost him his life.Literally “it is against his life”

chapter.pericope: Reiteration of the Warning Against a Strange Woman

ul.li1: 24And now, my children, listen to me,
ul.li2: and be attentive to the sayings of my mouth.
ul.li1: 25May your heart not turn aside to her ways;
ul.li2: do not stray into her path.
ul.li1: 26For many slain she has laid low,
ul.li2: and countlessOr “strong men” are all of her killings.
ul.li1: 27The ways of SheolA term for the place where the dead reside, i.e., the Underworld are her house,
ul.li2: descending to chambers of death.
